item.description:

item.title: Patient Perspective Talk
item.description: Join us as Mr. Lowden shares his inspiring story of perseverance and adaptation in the face of progressive vision loss. Born with high myopia and became monocular at age 18 after a giant retinal tear. Experiencing a recent decline in detail vision, including acuity and contrast sensitivity. Relies on a range of low vision devices, which he will demonstrate during his talk.

item.title: Finding the Balance in Sustainable Menstruation
item.description:
üåç Sustainability goes beyond recycling bins; it's also about how we care for our bodies and communities.
Join us in exploring how sustainability, period poverty, and menstrual equity intersect in the next installment of the Menstrual Equity Series, "Finding the Balance in Sustainable Menstruation"!
üí°Hosted by Karen Farley (they/their) Environmental researcher and recent master's graduate, Karen's findings led to the creation of "Period Pin", an online map connecting menstruators to over 2,000 product locations across Canada.
**Registration link in bio
üìÜ Tuesday, November 4th! üìçOnline

item.title: Applying Mathematical Models to Vaccination and Epidemiology
item.description:
Our first AMATH Prof Talk of the term is coming up soon!
Title: Applying Mathematical Models to Vaccination and Epidemiology Speaker: Prof. Chris Bauch Abstract: Vaccine refusal has enabled previously eliminated infectious diseases--such as measles and pertussis--to re-emerge in many populations. Vaccine refusal is driven by many factors, one of which is the presence or absence of the infectious disease that the vaccine itself prevents. This suggests that disease spread and vaccine decision-making are, in fact, two parts of a single coupled system of behaviour-disease interactions. Mathematical models have a long history of application in the population biology of human pathogens, including pediatric infectious diseases, and they are increasingly applied to coupled behaviour-disease interactions as well. In this talk I will give an overview of some simple mathematical models of vaccine refusal for pediatric infectious diseases, including a discussion of what they predict and how well they match up with observational data. I will also discuss extensions of these models to the COVID pandemic.
Pizza and refreshments available for PMC members.

item.title: Alum Spotlight Q&A: Tom Miller
item.description:
üåü Alum Spotlight Q&A: Tom Miller üåü
Curious about where an ActSci degree can take you beyond the traditional path? Meet Tom Miller ‚Äî a UW alum who started as an actuary, earned his FSA in 2019, pivoted into consulting, and now works at a startup using data to tackle the addiction crisis. Tom‚Äôs career spans technical modeling, client-facing strategy work, and mission-driven product building, and he‚Äôs excited to talk candidly about what he‚Äôs learned along the way.
üìç MC 4041‚Ä®üìÖ Nov 4‚Ä®üïî 5:00 ‚Äì 7:00 PM
What you‚Äôll get from this session: * How to leverage actuarial skills to move into consulting and startups * What earning the FSA opened up‚Äîand what it didn‚Äôt * Day-to-day realities of non-traditional actuarial roles * Practical advice on courses, co-op choices, and storytelling on your resume * Open Q&A‚Äîask anything!
All years welcome‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre exploring career options, planning a pivot, or just want inspiration from someone who‚Äôs done it.

item.title: Law and Economics: Rational and Objective or Fundamentally Unjust?
item.description:
We are happy to announce our Philosophy Talk of the term presented by Professor Patricia Marino, Law and economics: rational and objective or fundamentally unjust?
WHEN: Wednesday November 5th at 5pm WHERE: Hagey Hall Room 345 DESCRIPTION: Law and economics is the application of economic theory to legal reasoning: in this increasingly influential approach, laws are understood not in terms of justice and rights, but rather as efficient solutions to the problems of organizing society. In normative law and economics, the aim of the legal system is to maximize social welfare. Normative law and economics thus echoes the ethical theory of utilitarianism, where the right action is the one that produces the best consequences. Like utilitarianism, law and economics reasoning faces challenges to do with ethical values such as justice, fairness, and equality: what if the best consequences sacrifice some people's interests for the good of others, increase inequality, or violate other ethical norms? In this talk, I showcase these problems through examples related to tax policy, environmental injustice, and health care resource allocation; I then explain how proponents of law and economics respond to these challenges. We can then discuss together whether law and economics is a rational, objective alternative to arbitrary decision-making or whether its recommendations can be fundamentally unjust.
Snacks and drinks will be provided. This talk is open to all members of the UW community, no experience or expertise in philosophy required. We hope to see you there for an interesting philosophy talk and discussion on philosophy of economics!

item.title: 3Peas: Performative Edition
item.description:
üçµ 3Peas: Performative Edition üéß
It‚Äôs time to romanticize volleyball. ‚ú® Join us for our Performative 3Peas Tournament on Friday, November 7th, where we‚Äôll be serving performative energy both on and off the court. üèê
üìÜ Date: Friday, November 7 ‚è∞ Time: 3:00 PM ‚Äì 9:00 PM üè´ Location: CIF Gyms 1 & 2 üé≠ Theme: Performative üé∂ üèÖ Prizes: Winning team of 6 + Best Dressed Team
üë• Sign up as: ‚Ä¢ A team of 3 (female-identifying members) ‚Ä¢ Or as an individual and get matched with a team!
‚ú® Tournament Divisions & Caps: ‚Ä¢ Level 1/2/3 Tournament: Level cap of 7 ‚Ä¢ Level 3/4/5 Tournament: Level cap of 12 ‚Ä¢ All competitors must be evaluated this term in Levels 1‚Äì5 ‚Ä¢ These are two separate women‚Äôs tournaments (Level 1/2/3 and Level 3/4/5)
üèê Format: ‚Ä¢ Round Robins: Each trio plays 5‚Äì6 sets, randomly paired against other trios. ‚Ä¢ Finals: Top 2 teams (by sets won then point differential) each choose another trio to play with for finals.
üëâ Sign-ups open this Friday at 3 PM ‚Äî first come, first serve! Wait for your captain‚Äôs confirmation email before game day. üìç Link in our Linktree!
So grab your tote, sip your matcha, open up Clash Royale, and get ready to soft-serve your heart out. ‚òÅÔ∏èüçµüíø

item.title: Crown Conversations
item.description: Hi family! üëãüèæ Join BASE, LBIH (Lanterna Black Innovation Hub) and the Black Collective for ‚ÄúCrown Conversations‚Äù, a collaboration with their ‚ÄúFriday‚Äôs After 5‚Äùsessions at the EDI-R. We‚Äôll be talking about everything to do with Black hair and belonging. Topics will include: hair-typing and its origins, texturism within the Black community, hair styling and products, plus a discussion to share personal journeys and routines! üóìÔ∏è Friday, November 7th, 2025 ‚è±Ô∏è 5-7:30 PM üìçEast Campus 5 (EC5) -> Second floor -> Office of Equity, Diversity, Inclusion and Anti-Racism (EDI-R) üçï There will be pizza and other light refreshments available. See you soon!

General public: Meet the band members, learn about the band's! This event will be 19+. We'd love to meet you all before our big shows this term!

item.title: Badminton Ontario Circuit Tryouts
item.description:
BADMINTON ONTARIO CIRCUIT TRYOUTS ‚ÄºÔ∏è üóìÔ∏è We‚Äôll be hosting tryouts for our circuit team in two weeks, on Friday, November 7th, from 9:30 PM - 12:30 AM, during regular session. This is SEPARATE from varsity‚Äôs team.
‚ÄºÔ∏èYOU MUST BE A UWBC MEMBER TO PARTICIPATE (unless otherwise stated by the team)
‚úçÔ∏è Applicants must fill out the registration form and will be required to pay a tryout fee of $5.
üëü It is HIGHLY recommended to bring running shoes, along with your court shoes.
üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚Äç‚û°Ô∏è The first part of the tryout will be an outdoor run.
CIRCUIT INFORMATION üèÜ Badminton Ontario‚Äôs new circuit aims to give university club players the opportunity to represent their school while playing high-level, competitive badminton.
üèÖ This circuit will feature four tournaments, at the following locations: 1. Brock University (St. Catharines) 2. University of Waterloo (Waterloo) 3. University of Toronto (Scarborough) 4. Pan-Am Centre (Markham)
üè∏ Each of these tournaments will feature 5 events: - MS - WS - MD - WD - XD
üëØ As such, we‚Äôre aiming to take a maximum of 16 players. (8 men, 8 women).
üßë‚Äçüßí We will also be taking subs based on term/individual availabilities and injuries.
‚úÖ Thanks, and I hope to see you all at tryouts!
üçÄ Best of luck!

item.title: Inter-University Karate Seminar
item.description: The University of Waterloo Karate and Jujitsu club will be hosting an Inter-University Karate Seminar on Saturday, November 8, 2025. We will be inviting and collaborating with many esteemed Karate instructors and various Universities to join us! The schedule is currently focused on developing Kihon in the morning and Kata/Bunkai in the afternoon, with a focus on Goju-Ryu and Shotokan style Karate!

item.title: Model Workshop
item.description: Calling all Models! üåü We are hosting a Model Workshop on November 8th from 11:00 AM - 3:00 PM @ EV2 2002 This workshop is MANDATORY for all models and anyone is welcome to come by. Stop by and join in whether you are just starting or experienced! ü§ç

item.title: Tabletop Tavern
item.description:
Tabletop Tavern is here for its 5th running and we are back and better than ever! Sponsored by J&J Cards and Collectables & Ravenwood Tabletop, expect this now six-way collab event in SLC 1123 (The Bomber) Sat, Nov. 8th from 12-11pm between UW Board Games Club, WATSFiC, Deceptions Board Games, Pok√©mon Club, Yu-Gi-Oh Club, and the Magic the Gathering Club to be a day you don‚Äôt want to miss!
Come for a day of scheduled events, live performances, a raffle for prizes (sponsored by J&J‚Äôs and Ravenwood), a drinks bar (non-alcoholic), snacks, for-loan games (given you provide your WATCard or Valid ID), items for sale, and so much more!
For each scheduled event you take part in you will get a raffle ticket for a chance to win amazing sponsored prizes at the end of the night! The winners of WATSFiC‚Äôs D&D tournament get an additional ticket towards the raffle. To sign-up for WATSFiC‚Äôs tournament and guarantee a seat, please see their discord server posts. Walk-in is also available. Any volunteer DMs will also get a free drink from our drinks bar for your efforts!
Again, a big thanks to @jjcardsandcollectibles and @ravenwoodtabletop.ca for agreeing to sponsor the event and offer our raffle prizes, @acornpeanuts for the front poster design, @daidd_an for the rest of the poster designs, and to all the organizing clubs (@uwboardgames @uwdeception @uwyugioh @uwatsfic @uw_pokemon_club and Magic the Gathering) for working so hard to put this all together. We couldn‚Äôt have done it without you!
So with that being said, we hope to see you at Tabletop Tavern this term as we get back into the full swing of things! Check each club‚Äôs Discord server announcements for more details. If you want to keep up with each club, don‚Äôt hesitate to check out what they have coming up after and/or leading up to Tabletop Tavern!

item.title: STANK: Serve's Thanksgiving Annual N(v)olleyball Kompetition
item.description: ü•ß Prepare for a Feast of Fierce Volleyball! ü¶É As the leaves turn and the holiday spirit fills the air, it‚Äôs time for STANK: Serve‚Äôs Thanksgiving Annual N(v)olleyball Kompetition! Gather your team, bring your best plays, and get ready to serve up gratitude with spikes, digs, and fierce rallies. Let‚Äôs celebrate the season with some friendly competition and a full plate of fun! Event Details: üèê Date: Saturday, November 15th-16th (Overnight) ‚è∞ Time: 8pm to 8am üìç Location: PAC Main Gym + Small Gym üçÇ Team Sign-Up Form your crew of 6 to 9 players (only UWaterloo students with a valid athletics membership or alumni with a day pass) and choose your division: semi-competitive or competitive. Co-ed rules apply: all teams must have at least 2 female-identifying players on the court at all times. (Note: A female libero is required to serve for a middle.) ‚ö†Ô∏è NEW Semi-Comp Sign-Up Rules (Read Carefully!) To keep play balanced and fair this season: - Any male-identifying player rated Level 5 or of Level 5 ability must set or lib on a semi-comp team. - If you attended UW prior to the 5-level system (graduated before Fall 2023), the same rule applies if you were rated Level 4. - Spring levels are not included in this consideration. - If there‚Äôs any confusion, please reach out to an exec for clarification. - If your team has a Level 5 male player signed up for semi-comp, contact an exec to verify the validity of your team. - Players who are not evaluated this term may be removed from your team on the day of or asked to set/lib if necessary. üí∞ Pricing Regular (still fresh out of the coop): Register by Nov 3rd for $200 Both the form and payment must be completed by Nov 3rd @ 11:59pm. üìù How to Register Make your payment: https://warrior.uwaterloo.ca/Program/GetProgramDetails?courseId=e7072bd1-0754-4e99-9fbe-04a18228cfe1 Fill out the form: https://forms.office.com/r/twpLDkzmhD @everyone üèê Let‚Äôs spice up the season, rally together, and make this Thanksgiving one to remember!

item.description: Hey SAF students! Ready to burn off some post-midterm stress or spend a fun Sunday afternoon? item.title: AMATH Prof Talk
item.description:
Come join us for an AMATH Prof Talk on neural networks and dynamical systems!
Abstract: In machine learning, neural networks are often used in a feed-forward manner. Or, when a population of neurons is recurrently connected, the updates happen in synchronized jumps. But the neurons in your brain are operating in continuous time. I will show you some ways to bridge the gap to biology, and treat networks of interconnected neurons as a dynamical system. Then, we'll co-opt those networks to do our bidding, and get them to solve dynamical systems.
Pizza and refreshments will be provided to PMC members.

item.title: Esports & Gaming Industry Mixer
item.description:
The future of gaming is being built right here in Waterloo Region.
On November 19, we‚Äôre gathering the people who are shaping that future, from those who filled The Aud for the 2025 Call of Duty League Championships to those building new esports programs in local schools and campuses.
Join us at @workatcommons for a night of conversation, connection, and celebration as we toast to another incredible year for esports and gaming.
Tickets are free but spots are limited. RSVP through the link in bio.
üéÆ

item.title: From Outages to Ownership
item.description:
From Outages to Ownership: Disaster Recovery, DNS, and Career Journeys in Okta Engineering
Ready to see how a top tech company handles the really big challenges? Join us and our Okta engineers for an evening focused on the critical work that keeps our services running; even when major outages happen. Our Staff Software Engineer will kick off the event with a fascinating technical talk, diving into DNS, redundancy, and disaster recovery based on her real-world experience at Okta. It‚Äôs a timely look at how engineering teams build for reliability at scale.
After the deep-dive, you‚Äôll hear from a panel of Engineers from various teams as they share their own career paths, offer a peek into their day-to-day work, and give you practical advice for launching your career. Stick around for our informal networking mixer to connect one-on-one with the team and ask any final questions!
üîó Link in bio to register

item.title: Digital Marketing With AI Tailor Made Onward Israel
item.description: From our friends at @gotailormade ! Immerse yourself in the vibrant culture and dynamic energy of Israel with this unique 4-week program in central Tel Aviv. Develop cutting edge skills in AI-powered digital marketing, explore Israel like a local, and gain hands on experience with real world projects.
